body: Even if you can't pull out a single page, let me take a look at it and see what I can do.
ok.  downloading.  wasn't expecting a cd sized image...
And that's a small one. Didn't want to upload the full sized ones ;)

Ok. Imagemagick helpfully converted that into 1000 separate tiff files, each ~400k, 1024x304, 12bit gray with no compression. (Apparently it can convert all of them, but not one of them. Yay.)

I see the 12bit packing there.
I hadn't thought of using imagemagick. I have amended the original post to include both samples.

Imagemagick is a good swiss army knife for pulling apart images to see what's going on. On the other hand, it doesn't always give you what you want. I'm currently trying to get a good 12 bit test image with known values (e.g. a ramp from 0x000 to 0x0ff, or at least known integer values for some pixels) so that I can ensure that I'm not getting bits badly twiddled. But changing the depth of an 8 bit image normalizes the values so that they go full range, and I haven't figured out how to turn that off, at least in a way that I _know_ what the values are supposed to be. 

So, current progress is that I've got I12 files unpacking to I16, but I'm stuck on the verification. Do you happen to have a way to dump one frame to raw 16bit values (with known endianess)?

This is the exact same image, saved from the camera in [12bit](https://www.dropbox.com/s/cm5ewx97abhn5kv/12bit.tif) (actual chip bit depth), [16bit padded left](https://www.dropbox.com/s/jmsxek2hjox5l58/16bit-left.tif) and [16bit padded right](https://www.dropbox.com/s/80vy5bj2uxnzz97/16bit-right.tif). The camera offers the option of selecting "high" or "low" bits when saving at 16bit, I read this as padding left/right, but that might be wrong.

I'm getting the padded left and padded right ones being exactly the same: 

```
md5sum *
7cd4d8c50dbb93ef9783a4962afe79a0  12bit.tif
2cc0d9a86f09a9cc2561d4419ddb8888  16bit-left.tif
2cc0d9a86f09a9cc2561d4419ddb8888  16bit-right.tif
```

Imagemagick is reporting that the max value in the 16 bit ones is 255,255,255, which would correspond to an 8 bit image padded left. It's also reporting that it's an MSB oriented image, which is... not in agreement with the II\* prefix. 

Like other swiss army knives, sometimes it's not really the right tool for the job.

Ok, I managed to get imagemagick to give me two equivalent files, one was cropped from one frame of your original, one was converted to be the same data in a 16bit form, and I was able to get the images to match. 

Try out cc5e8f0 on your machine and see if that does it for you.  I still need test on a bigendian machine, but I should have access to one of them around here somewhere.

issue.title: Support for reading 12 bit tiff images
issue.body:
Fixes #414. 

  x Needs tested on Bigendian systems.  
  x Should be tested with libtiff as well.

body: Yes that works, thank you very much!

issue.title: Support for Saving 12-Bit JPEG
issue.body:
### What did you do?
Try to sve 12 bit JPEG.

### What did you expect to happen?
File saved with 12 bit JPEG.

### What actually happened?
```
/Users/alex/.virtualenvs/work/lib/python2.7/site-packages/PIL/JpegImagePlugin.pyc in _save(im, fp, filename)
    590         rawmode = RAWMODE[im.mode]
    591     except KeyError:
--> 592         raise IOError("cannot write mode %s as JPEG" % im.mode)
    593
    594     if im.mode == 'RGBA':

IOError: cannot write mode I;16 as JPEG
```
### What versions of Pillow and Python are you using?
`4.0.0`

```python
Image.fromarray(np.ones((10,10), np.uint16)).save('/Users/alex/Desktop/test.jpeg')
```

Related: https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/issues/414

Some work on libjpeg: https://trac.osgeo.org/gdal/wiki/TIFF12BitJPEG
